prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for kicking a guy out of my hobby group because of his concealed gun?
I am in a little board game group that has been meeting regularly for the past six months. We used to have our game nights at a local hobby shop, but since we've gotten closer and the shop is in not the best part of town, have recently decided to start doing it at my house instead.

There's five of us total and one guy, "Jim" has a concealed carry permit and carries a gun with him. I know this because he's mentioned that he's always armed. I am very anti-gun but it had never come up before. Before our first game night at my place I told Jim privately that I don't want any guns in my house and that he would have to leave his in his truck if he brang it. He gave kind of an acknowledging but not exactly affirming response.

Then after our first game session at my house, one of the other group members told me on her way out that Jim had told her he still had his gun with him while I was in the kitchen out of earshot. I texted Jim and told me he had been extremely disrespectful and that this wasn't a game, and he could not come to my house again if he was going to have a gun on him. His response was "Fine, guess I won't be coming then," and he effectively quit the group.

The reaction with the rest of the group is split. One person doesn't care whether Jim participates or not, one person says it was "harsh but fair" and that Jim wasn't really kicked out per se, and one person thinks I am being a shrew and shouldn't have been so uptight about the gun after just one session, since he's never had to leave it behind before.

My point of view is that it's my house and my rules, and I don't think it's an unreasonable rule to not want a gun in my home. I put my foot down the first time it happened because it was a serious matter and not like he brought the wrong snacks or something. Jim keeps texting me going back and forth between saying "lose my number" and sending me links to propaganda supporting his viewpoint.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person in the situation is in the wrong. The scenario is about a board game group where one member, Jim, carries a concealed gun. The author, who hosts the meetings, asked Jim not to bring the gun into their home. Jim didn't comply, and the author kicked him out. Now the group is divided on whether that was justified.

First, I need to consider the legal aspects. Concealed carry laws vary by location, but generally, if someone has a permit, they can carry in most public places. However, private property rules can differ. The author's home is private, so they might have the right to set rules about guns on their property. Some states allow landlords or private property owners to prohibit guns, but others might have restrictions. I'm not sure about the exact laws here, but the key point is that the author's home is their space.

Next, the social dynamics. The author made their stance clear before the first meeting, asking Jim to leave the gun in his truck. Jim didn't follow through, which led to the author taking action. The author's reasoning is about personal comfort and safety. Even if Jim had a permit, the author's right to feel safe in their home is significant. The other group members have mixed reactions, but the author's decision is based on their own boundaries.

Another angle is communication. The author gave a clear warning beforehand. Jim's response wasn't a direct agreement, which might have been a mistake. If he had asked for an exception or there was a misunderstanding, maybe the situation could have been different. But the author made their position known, and Jim still brought the gun, which the author saw as disrespectful.

The ongoing texts from Jim after being asked to leave might indicate he's trying to keep the conversation going or is upset about being excluded. However, the author's main issue was about the gun, not the texts. The texts are part of the aftermath, not the initial decision.

Considering all this, the author acted to enforce their home rules, which is their right. Even if Jim had a concealed carry permit, the author can set terms for their own property. The action was based on prior agreement, so the author isn't in the wrong. The answer should be B.
